section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The Sovereign Lord is the nine treasures for me.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

text: ਸੰਪੈ ਹੇਤੁ ਕਲਤੁ ਧਨੁ ਤੇਰੈ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: The possessions and the spouse to which the mortal is lovingly attached, are Your wealth, O Lord. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: sanpai hēt kalat dhan tērai .1. rahāu .

text: ਕਹਿ ਕਬੀਰ ਤੇ ਜਨ ਪਰਵਾਨ ॥ ਨਿਰਮਲ ਤੇ ਜੋ ਰਾਮਹਿ ਜਾਨ ॥੬॥੩॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Says Kabeer, those humble beings are approved and pure, who know the Lord. ||6||3||

transliteration.text: kah kabīr tē jan paravān . niramal tē jō rāmah jān .6.3.

text: ਮਨੁ ਕਰਿ ਮਕਾ ਕਿਬਲਾ ਕਰਿ ਦੇਹੀ ॥

translation.text: Let your mind be Mecca, and your body the temple of worship.

translation.text: Let the Supreme Guru be the One who speaks. ||1||

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: O Mullah, utter the call to prayer.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

text: ਤੋਰਉ ਨ ਪਾਤੀ ਪੂਜਉ ਨ ਦੇਵਾ ॥
section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I do not pick leaves as offerings, and I do not worship idols.

transliteration.text: tōrau n pātī pūjau n dēvā .

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. It is a kind of fanaticism, where there is a feeling of not being aware or caring about anything else. The emotions conveyed are those of contentment and of being absorbed in a steadfast belief or faith. In this Raag, the soul is relaying the happiness that the mind could potentially experience if it joined in with this devotion.

author.author: Saint Kabir
author.description:
Saint Kabir [1440 - 1518] was a Muslim mystic born in Varanasi in India, whose 541 hymns are included in the Guru Granth Sahib. His writings about God are full of love and devotion, very direct and striking in appeal.

The birth of Kabir remains to this day shrouded in mystery and legend. Authorities disagree on both when he was born and who his parents were. One legend proclaims a divine virginal birth. His mother was reputed to have been of the Brahman caste and to have become pregnant after a visit to a Hindu shrine.

Because she was unwed, she abandoned Kabir, who was found and adopted by a Muslim weaver. That his early life began as a Muslim there is no doubt, although he later became influenced by the Hindu ascetic, Ramananda, who he accepted as his Guru.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Without devotional worship of the Lord, service is useless. ||2||

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: I worship the True Guru; forever and ever, I surrender to Him.

melody.description: Bhairao embodies the soul’s faith and heartfelt devotion towards The Creator. section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: By such service, I find peace in the Court of the Lord. ||3||

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: People say that Kabeer has gone insane.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Only the Lord realizes the secret of Kabeer. ||4||6||

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: Turning away from the world, I have forgotten both my social class and ancestry.

section: Bhairao - Bhagtah Ki Bani (Teachings Of The Saints)

translation.text: My weaving now is in the most profound celestial stillness. ||1||

translation.text: I have no quarrel with anyone.
